messageBody:
Was I the only person to be saddened by this announcement? Maybe I'm
just being sentimental here but the Graphical TestRunner's green bar/red
bar was one of the earliest delights of Junit.

Besides, as a casual user of Java I have yet to find the energy to learn
an IDE. When I do have to code Java I generally use my normal text
editor and the graphical test runner, which I find is quicker and easier
to use than the text version.

I know Kent has an evangelising streak - automated unit testing,
xp/agile, etc - which he has used well in the service of the software
community but I think insisting on the use of an IDE is a crusade too
far.

Cheers, APC

-----Original Message-----
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Kent Beck
Sent: 18 August 2005 17:07
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: RE: [junit] Some questions about JUnit 4

Elliotte,

Thank you for the offer, but we are fairly certain that we do not want
to include the graphical runners in JUnit 4. I can see that they might
be useful in a teaching situation, but we are assuming that an IDE will
always be available or that the textual interface will suffice.

Sincerely yours,

Kent Beck
Three Rivers Institute
